item.title: Morgan Mayday's Guide to Going Vegan
item.description:
The first version of this guide is being published 05 February 2026, and will be continually updated as I acquire more good recipes. If you have a good, easy recipe, email it to me at me@morganmay.day and I might give it a shot :)

Why?

I’ve detailed my reasons why, but you may have your own! I won’t waste time speculating.

If you’ve been struggling to make the whole change at once, I highly recommend taking it in steps. Going vegetarian is way easier than going vegan, making it a really good stepping-stone.

item.title: Taking Relationships Seriously, and the Importance of Living Models
item.description:
Shoutout, as usual, to my colleague morrigan. Most of these thoughts were cohered with or to it last night.

I sigh. “Listen,” I say, gesture as if I’m indicating the puff of heat into the midnight air, “you gotta promise not to get weird or attacked, yeah? Cause what I’m about to say is…”

I ruminate, for a second. “Not necessarily objective,” I settle on, “definitely not nonjudgemental, but.” Shake my head. “I judge because I think these are skills that can be learned. I have high standards. That’s fine. If I approved of everything unconditionally, my Recognition would be at best an atrophied mess. If I disapprove, that’s not a statement of ‘I don’t love you anymore’ or ‘I don’t think your thoughts have value’ or ‘I think you’re worthless’. It just means I think you have room to grow. If you’re gonna get weird or attacked about this, now’s your chance to leave.”

item.title: Hacking Yourself Does, Technically, Work
item.description:
When I say I’m hacking something together, that’s a very specific statement.

To create something on something else, to patch together a solution from disparate pieces onto an existing workflow, that’s something I do all the time in computer science, and every time I do it, I later regret it. I’m not gonna stop, because it’s often the most efficient way for me to learn–for example, I learned to write Nix by editing .nix files with no fucking clue what I was doing and then parsing the error messages–but it is bad practices.

item.title: Empathy, People, and You, or: the Flesh Racket
item.description:
With thanks, deep and irrevocable, to morrigan.

Required reading: Not A Person.

“The nature of empathy and sympathy,” I don’t say, “that I’ve met very few people who understand, is that they’re rarely-to-never going to be exactly right. I don’t really think of myself as having sympathy, because sympathy is understanding how others feelâ€”I can guess, and I can guess very, very well; my models are generally really good, but I will never be physically inside someone else’s head. The mistake of sympathy and empathy is thinking you’re always right.”

item.title: Emotions vs Reason, and Self Control
item.description:
Association with To Desire, amongst other things.

“The register” will require its own whole grimoire page. The working definition for this piece is “a tool in the firmware layer that logs cognition, allowing for better metacognition.”

Minds, broadly, react to stimuli. The human animal reacts to stimuli in one way: thought.

For the purposes of this piece, subconscious thought is any electrical impulse in the brain that results in consequence without being registered in what we call the register. These most often will be things like ducking at a loud noise, yanking your hand away from a hot stove, or flinching from a blow–sometimes, you will have them registered, but most of the time, the neuromuscular impulse happens without consulting you. These are things we would consider on the layer of cognitive hardware–things that do not bother to be registered, because doing so wastes time that, evolutionarily, not wasting leads to a higher survival rate.

item.title: To Desire
item.description:
“I don’t want to do this” is a very simple statement.

We live in a world where we have to do things we find unpleasant.
I do not like brushing my teeth. I also have to brush my teeth.
It’s worse, for a lot of folk in school or assignment-based workspaces. A lot of the time, you have to suffer through boring, routine, difficult but not challenging, or overly challenging tasks, and those suck. I don’t like doing them. They do not bring me joy; this is why I’m not currently planning on going back to college.

item.title: Don't Apologise To Me
item.description:
Edit 19 Nov 2025: Correction for the unapology, added by Caroline.

‘Sorry’ is all well and good, but what are you going to do about it?
Let me explain. There are three kinds of apologies.

One: the superficial apology. “Oop, sorry” is the most benign form of this, running into someone and apologising and moving on is, like, just a generally nice thing to do. However, a lot of people extrapolate this into a counterproductive form.
Generally, apologising for something that doesn’t matter just obligates the other conversational participants to comfort you. The more self-flagellating the apology, the worse this is, because it carries over into the way I approach other apologies from you in future. If you do something that’s, for lack of a better phrase, kinda sucks, I’ll point it out to you if I trust you not to self-flagellate about it and just to use the data. If you’ve done something that hurts or irritates me, the last thing I’m going to want is to have to comfort you out of a spiral. I’ll do it, because as a general rule I think that not doing it would be incompatible with who I want to be, but I will not be bringing data to you in future.

item.title: Agency, Manipulation, Coercion, and Abuse
item.description:
Note: Rewritten with epistemic corrections here

I’m cracking the top of my can and sitting down next to you on the stormwall. Listen, honey, I tell you, and shift a bit to get comfortable, to explain this I’m gonna have to get kinda metaphorical. If you’re not in a brainspace for a weird conversation, now’s not the time.

A lot of people consider manipulation a type of abuse. “You’re making someone act against their will,” well, yes and no. If the magician nudges a card, makes you more likely to pick it when they say “any card,” is that abusive?
